name: Letter from Thomas Lowe, St. Jones, to Edmund Waring
description: Understanding that differences have grown between Mr. Bagot and Mrs. Okeover over a letter she is supposed to have written to Lowe about his brother William, he affirms that he never received such a letter.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from John Lumley, Baron Lumley, Nonsuch, to Richard Bagot
description: Bagot having previously gone to Mr. Rugeley of Hawksyard to arrange marriage between Mr. Rugeley's daughter and Bagot's godson (Lumley's nephew) Richard Rugeley, Lumley now asks that he intercede again and try for the same terms, now that the young people have alienated both parents by precipitate headstrong marriage.

name: Letter from Jane Lycett, Shugborough (Shutbore), to Dorothy Okeover
description: A kinsman, Francis Norman, has long failed to pay her and her husband money that he promised when they let him sell their land. They are old, unable to work, and in want. They will settle for 7.

name: Letter from Lewis Bagot, London, to Walter Bagot
description: The privy seals delivered. Sir Walter Aston has promised Lewis the use of his chamber when he leaves. Lewis in commons at one of the Inns of Court. Sir Richard Leveson to accompany the Earl of Nottingham on an embassage to Spain. The Kynnersley-Trew case is followed hard by Sir Walter Chetwynd and Mr. Wolseley (Wouslye).

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from John? Mabull to Mr. Newman, his godson
description: Sends two commissions to be sealed by Mr. Walter Bagot. Bagot is much beholden to Mr. Chamberlain for his care in the Cheney business; he kept in his hands the particular signed by Chamberlain and Lord Knollys. Bagot ought to send up to the court a draught of the assignment of the wardship to Cheney. Lyvesey the cuckold is committed.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Sir John Manners, Haddon, Derbyshire, to Richard Bagot
description: Asks the discharge of Hugh Sleighe from the assessment for one corselet; his ability is mean and he has many children.

name: Letter from Sir Roger Manwood, London, to Richard Bagot and Ralph Sneyd (Sneade)
description: Alexander Bolte was at last assizes committed to prison on suspicion of felony. He has a large family to support, and Sir Roger asks his release on bail.

name: Letter from Castillian Mason to the Justices of the Peace in Staffordshire?
description: The steward, the treasurer, and the comptroller of the household wrote on April 3rd commending Mason as undertaker for the composition for oxen and sheep. His demand is 9 10 shillings. for a pair of oxen, over the king's demand, and 11 shillings, 4 pence for each sheep.

agent.name: the Justices of the Peace in Staffordshire?

name: Letter from Robert Master, Lichfield, to Walter Bagot
description: Young Cliffe was arrested but escaped; when the bailiffs went to Edial to take him, five men set on them and Hollis was slain. Hopes Bagot will favor this poor old man.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

name: Letter from Sir Walter Mildmay to Richard Bagot
description: Certain lands in the manor of Burton Extra having been let to Agnes Steele, widow, and now being claimed by one William Twyner, Bagot is to investigate and see that the widow is protected if her title is good.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

name: Letter from William Milwarde to Walter Bagot
description: Desires Bagot to see that the widow of Emmes, a maimed soldier, receives the arrears in his pension. Bagot may get a new trial with an indifferent jury in his Court of Wards cause; Saintlowe Kniveton is searching records.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile

name: Letter from William Milwarde to Walter Bagot
description: Showing cause to challenge some jurors, Bagot ought to have a jury of those dwelling near Derby, the old jury being mainly Scarsdale men, many wearing the sheriff's cloth. He must have good proofs for the tenure; the old jury will hardly be indifferent.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from William Milwarde, Eaton, to Francis Kynnersley
description: Sent a draft of their agreement to Kynnersley's father, who will deliver it to him; hopes for final agreement on Thursday. Also, Francis Kynnersley's response. He showed to his father William Milwarde's letter saying that the father would deliver an agreement. But he refused to do so before seeing Bagot. Asks Bagot to meet him and his father.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

name: Letter from Edward Moreton, Stafford, to Walter Bagot
description: A point-by-point rebuttal of a letter of Bagot's to Worswick defending one Pavier and raising objections to the mayor's prosecution.

name: Letter from Lewis Bagot, London, to Walter Bagot
description: Having difficulty getting a chamber; Sir Walter Aston left town without a word. The king is at Royston.

name: Letter from Margaret Mumford to Walter Bagot
description: Lady Cheney sent her brewer, Drakford, to ask for her man, the bearer thereof. This man has a desire to serve Bagot, and she hopes Bagot will be a good master to him.

name: Letter from Thomas Nabbs to Walter Bagot
description: There is process out for Sir William Chetwynd (deceased), Sir Edward Littleton, and Bagot himself for payment of the prisoners of the King's Bench and the Marshalsea. A cepi corpus is impossible.

name: Letter from Sir Richard Newdigate to Sir Edward Bagot, bart.?
description: Detailed instructions concerning the transfer of unspecified property to Bagot.

name: Letter from Sir Richard Newdigate to Sir Edward Bagot
description: Discussion of complex financial transactions involving a Mr. Monteage, Sir Francis Burdett, Sir Robert Shirley, and others.

name: Letter from Sir Richard Newdigate to Sir Edward Bagot
description: Has received 900, for which he has signed a bond and for which he is indebted to Bagot. The 500 have not been sent for.

description: Advice concerning rents and tythes of unidentified property.

name: Letter from Sir Richard Newdigate to Sir Edward Bagot
description: An obscure letter mainly about a suit of his cousin Scrimsher's.

name: Letter from Roger North, Baron North, Court at Whitehall, to Sir John Bowes and Walter Bagot
description: Mr. Stephen Ashby of Hanbury is in trouble through the connivance of a lewd kinsman of his wife's. He stole a horse and put it into Ashby's stable, where it was found. Asks favorable treatment for Ashby.

agent.name: Roger North, Baron North, Court at Whitehall
Sir John Bowes and Walter Bagot

name: Letter from Charles Howard, Earl of Nottingham, the Court at Greenwich, to Richard Bagot
description: Asks a lease and other kindnesses for his man,

agent.name: Charles Howard, Earl of Nottingham, the Court at Greenwich

name: Letter from Lewis Bagot, London, to Walter Bagot
description: Apologizes for his long stay in London and for not accomplishing his mission there; lives there more contented than at home; will hasten home if summoned.

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

name: Letter from Charles Howard, Earl of Nottingham to Sir Simon Weston and Walter Bagot
description: The writer, a Justice in Eyre, is in charge of the selling of forests belonging to the king and at his wishes. The addressees have been appointed commissioners to make sale of suitable properties in Staffordshire, and will soon receive their commissions.

agent.name: Sir Simon Weston and Walter Bagot

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Richard Oake to Richard Bagot
description: He, formerly having been disciplined by the bishop, Thomas Bentham, for a fault involving a marriage and papists at Stone, has conferred with the bishop and found his attitude softened through Bagot's intercession, which he hopes will continue. The reading of the writer's surname is uncertain; Cooke is possible.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Dorothy Okeover, London, to Richard Bagot
description: Hopes that he can without suit get the money belonging to her maid Jobson. It is rumored that the Scottish king and queen are to visit soon; does not expect much manifestation of joy over this. May God make the young queen a better woman than her mother-in-law. Sir Francis Walsingham is dead. Anthony waits at court; Lettice plies her virginals.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Dorothy Okeover to Lewis Bagot
description: Asks Lewis to sign and seal a lease already signed by her brother (Lewis's father), the lease to fall to Lewis's brother upon her decease. His father is displeased at Lewis's long absence. A copy in Walter Bagot's hand. Also, a copy of Lewis's answer. He is willing to sign a lease, but prefers to wait until his return to the country.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Dorothy Okeover, Leacroft, to Walter Bagot
description: Her nephew Harvey Bagot has promised to confirm her lease by fine, and she has asked her nephew Edmund Waring to help and to defray all costs.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Dorothy Okeover to Walter Bagot
description: The people at Okeover put off payment; Philip Eaton does not pay; Francis Norman not only has not paid the Michaelmas rent nor gathered her Bagots Bromley rents, but owes her money for corn. Her nephew Richard Bagot is to help her collect her rents when he returns form Derbyshire. Wants Bagot's help. Asks after her sister Trew.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso || leaf 2 recto

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Dorothy Okeover, Snelston, to Walter Bagot
description: Sir Oliver and Lady Cheney came to Okeover yesterday; Brunt reports they will winter in London. Bagot's little son ward, Rowland Okeover, age 8 is with them and has the ague. Lady Cheney blames Bagot in the Cates business, her intelligence being from R. Wray.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Dorothy Okeover, Snelston, to Walter Bagot
description: The enclosed letter, obtained by nephew Waring, will expose the lies told against her. Her innocency will plead for her. Let them spit their malice.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Philip Okeover, Okeover, to Richard Bagot
description: His friend Richard Crompton having begged of the Lord Treasurer the keeping of the court at Burton and the leases of some land and some rooms in the house, the Lord Treasurer also asks Bagot to grant these requests in so far as he can.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Philip Okeover, Okeover, to Walter Bagot
description: Asks Bagot to send him a saddle and headpiece like Bagot's own, for which he will send money. Smith is to be trusted though he has dealt badly with him in the past; he has nothing to do with the Copistake. Having taken the first recognizance, he hopes Bagot will forbear.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Lewis Bagot, London, to Walter Bagot
description: Delivered the letter to Mr. Eldred; has received several motions to the same effect marriage?; hopes to meet with one who will content his father.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Rowland Okeover, London, to Walter Bagot
description: Understanding from his brother Philip that Bagot has in his keeping the great indenture of the Okeover entail, asks that it be returned to his brother. Francis promised to send word of his daughter Dorothy Okeover, but has not. Hopes to see them soon.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 recto

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 2 verso

name: Letter from Anthony Oldham to Walter Bagot?
description: Understanding that Mr. Kynnersley intends to bail Mr. Browne, begs Bagot to prevent it because with Browne free Oldham will go in fear of his life.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from William Osborne, London, to Richard Bagot
description: Osborne's grandfather mortgaged a piece of land called Hetley to Bagot's grandfather, who, refusing timely payment, entered on the land and kept possession. Osborne's father died just before winning suit for the land, and he hopes Bagot will now be reasonable and so avoid suit.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Margaret Overton, Eccleshall, to Richard Bagot
description: The semi-annual payment of 10 on her annuity was due at Christmas; asks prompt payment. Her husband's (bishop of Coventry and Lichfield) servant, Henry Halfpenny, has signed (by mark) an acquittance for the amount.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from William Overton, Bishop of Lichfield and Coventry, Lichfield, to Sir Edward Aston, Sir Edward Littleton, Richard Bagot and others
description: Has received a commission from the queen requiring him and the addressees to take order concerning seminary priests and Jesuits; they are to meet at Eccleshall Church on the 22nd of December next.

agent.name: William Overton, Bishop of Lichfield and Coventry, Lichfield
Sir Edward Aston, Sir Edward Littleton, Richard Bagot and others

name: Letter from William Overton, Bishop of Lichfield and Coventry, Lichfield, to Walter Bagot
description: Has received the certificate signed by Bagot and Mr. Bowyer, and approves, but has, with Sir Edward Littleton and others, called a general meeting of justices to be held in Lichfield in Whitsun week and thinks a certificate signed by all will better serve the Privy Council's requirements.

agent.name: William Overton, Bishop of Lichfield and Coventry, Lichfield

name: Letter from Thomas Paget, Baron Paget, London, to Richard Bagot
description: Thanks for past good will and for support in the matter that his servant Ensore has told Bagot of. Will repose trust in Bagot if things come to an extremity; is grateful for Mrs. Bagot's good inclination.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Thomas Paget, Baron Paget, London, to Richard Bagot
description: Perceives by Bagot's letter that ill feelings have arisen between Bagot and Mr. Cupper; does not understand the matter, but will not let this come between Bagot and him.

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 recto

folgerRelatedItems.@id: DAP internal ID for the following rootfile
folgerRelatedItems.label: leaf 1 verso

name: Letter from Thomas Paget, Baron Paget, Burton-upon-Trent, to Richard Bagot
description: The bearer's uncle, Richard Scragge, is tenant for his life of a farm of Bagot's and is willing to resign his interest to his nephew at his death; asks Bagot's favor.

name: Letter from William Paget, Baron Paget, London, to Walter Bagot
description: Certain officials of the town of Bromley are intransigent about the transfer of land to them for a school.

name: Letter from Lewis Bagot, London, to Walter Bagot
description: Has been a disparagement to his house and a disgrace to himself; prays for forgiveness, and hopes no longer to live than he will honor his father and mother. Endorsed Lewes his last letters.

name: Letter from William Paget, Baron Paget, London, to Walter Bagot
description: Agrees to the settlement about John Swayn's servants, but now Wakelin complains of receiving bodily injury at their hands; if this is true he deserves compensation.

name: Letter from Richard Paramore to Richard Bagot, high sheriff of the county of Staffordshire
description: Thanks for his forwardness in promoting justice; but the writer's adversaries claim the land, allowing him only the manor house; prays Bagot to persevere and secure him rents and profits. See L.a.764 and Shaw, II, 5.

agent.name: Richard Bagot, high sheriff of the county of Staffordshire

name: Letter from Mercurius Patten, Clement's Inn, London, to Richard Bagot
description: An account of a voyage to Antwerp in February, the receiving there of the Duke of Anjoy, his creation as Duke of Brabant, his oath, and other details.

name: Letter from Mercurius Patten, Westminster, to Walter Bagot
description: His servant passing through Staffordshire, he sends greetings. Is a prisoner in his own house, scarce daring to go out. Has but once seen Bagot's sister, his own godmother, since his coming.

name: Letter from Mercurius Patten, Westminster, to Walter Bagot
description: Sends two remedies for deafness. If Mrs Bagot were to bestow a piece of Bacon on so poor a household as his, he would accept it.

name: Letter from Sir Amias Paulet, Fotherinhay, to Richard Bagot
description: The bearer, John Porter, holds certain copyhold lands for his own life at Abbot's Bromley; the Earl of Essex has asked that he be allowed to surrender them and take them again to himself, his wife, and his son. Bagot is to see it done; Mr. Fynnye will cause a new copy to be made at the next court.

name: Letter from Sir Amias Paulet, Fotherinhay, to Richard Bagot
description: As steward of the Lord Paget's late lands, he has no intention of bestowing Blythe's copyhold on one of Fynnye's kinsmen; asks that Sir Walter Aston's servant be admitted at once at the Lord Treasurer's request.

name: Letter from Sir Amias Paulet, London, to Richard Bagot
description: Asks Bagot to send a buck from one of Lord Paget's parks to Lady Golding. Has sent to speak with Richard Broughton; has received Mr. Darrell's acquittancce and will send Bagot the 70 at his convenience.

name: Letter from Sir Amias Paulet, Twickenham, to Richard Bagot
description: The bearer, Cecily Nevill, has petitioned the queen for twelve trees from Cannock Wood to repair her house; but Mr. Herbert, the Master of Requests, loth to have the queen bothered at so busy a time, has offered three trees. Asks Bagot to see them delivered. Her husband was maimed in the wars.

name: Letter from Sir Amias Paulet, The Court, to Richard Bagot, deputy lieutenant
description: Commends Fulke Greville to Bagot's friendship in the execution of his commission.

name: Letter from Richard Bagot to Richard Broughton (his son-in-law)
description: Angry over his daughter Margaret's marriage. Cousin Newport lingers on and has sent some money. Bagot has paid Mrs. Overton. Sir George Bromley's letters delayed. The dean will let Essex have his house in Lichfield. Mr. Gresley has broken his word over a distress. Asks that Essex be reminded of his promised contribution to the shire hall, now building.

name: Letter from Sir Amias Paulet, The Court, to Richard Bagot, deputy lieutenant
description: Passes on a request made by the Earl of Essex for a brace of bucks for Mr. Littleton out of one of the parks formerly Lord Paget's.

name: Letter from Anthony Pembridge, Hereford, to Walter Bagot and Sir Simon Weston
description: Thanks for care of the Earl of Essex's affairs. The late earl having promised Francis Keene a certain tenement, he is to be put in possession; if some arrangement can be worked out for Hill, so much the better.

agent.name: Walter Bagot and Sir Simon Weston

name: Letter from Anthony Pembridge, Inner Temple, London, to Walter Bagot and Sir Simon Weston
description: The Earl of Essex will thank them more adequately for their care of his affairs. Stidman has been fully recompensed and must now begin paying the rent they have settled on.

agent.name: Walter Bagot and Sir Simon Weston

name: Letter from Anthony Pembridge, Inner Temple, London, to Walter Bagot and Sir Simon Weston
description: John Stidman to have the property at half rent. Amery has his land at 5 shillings a year, while the earl's outrents for it are 29 shillins, 10 pence. Now, though his lease forbids transfer without license from the lord, Amery has passed the land to Hill; Hill can be required to pay the outrent of surrender the estate.

agent.name: Walter Bagot and Sir Simon Weston

name: Letter from Anthony Pembridge, London, to Walter Bagot
description: Understand that certain evidences and court rolls of the Earl of Essex's property have come to Bagot's hands, and asks that Bagot send them by Cholmley to Anthony Bagot for perusal; wishes to be told of the nature of the documents.

name: Letter from John Persehouse, Walsall, to Walter Bagot
description: The bearer, Richard Aldred, buying nine sheep, five of them were soon challenged as stolen; one Hart brought to him the stranger who sold Aldred the sheep. The writer has long known Aldred and thinks him honest; wants Bagot to sift the matter.
